awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Next Generation, Data-Centric Supercomputer
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will support the acquisition of a data centric supercomputer at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI). This instrument will lead to significant advancements in science and engineering problems currently being tackled at RPI's Center for Computational Innovations (CCI) for applications including: the definition of new designed materials, applying active flows control for energy savings and microbiological systems modeling for medical treatment planning. The research will also include the development of new extreme-scale simulation technologies, graph analysis algorithms and the construction of entirely new simulation workflows. Hundreds of researchers and students from over 20 universities, 5 DOE national laboratories, 3 major industrial research centers (Corning, GE and IBM), 50 faculty, 4 start-ups across 11 U.S. states will take advantage of this proposed cyberinstrument to continue making a deep impact on their research. Student participation has been key to CCI's current success and national interest is anticipated not only due to the instrument's ability to advance current research but also due to its potential as a prototype model for future exascale systems.  Students engaged in projects supported by the instrument will become the next generation of compute and data intensive experts.

The new instrument integrates IBM POWER9 CPUs with next generation NVIDIA Volta GPUs into a hardware accelerated unified memory system (e.g., cache coherent). Additionally, all compute nodes are augmented with non-volatile memory storage, and a subset of the nodes include FPGA acceleration. The system will be used by faculty, students and CCI collaborators to address current barriers caused by the need to interact with massive data volumes that are used in and produced by next generation simulation tools. The cyberinstrument and algorithmic developments to be carried out will enable a new level of understanding and enhance our ability to solve many key challenges including: the accurate diagnosis of breast cancer directly from large-scale image datasets; semantic integration of the abundance of heterogeneous, multimodal, and multiscale data to improve personal health; modeling plasmas in fusion reactors; modeling active flow control devices that will greatly increase the weather conditions under which wind turbines will produce electricity; and combined biological data and model integration on molecular, cellular, and organ levels to understand organism-level phenomena and gain predictive understanding in systems biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In April, 2019, a new IBM data centric supercomputer system was purchased and installed at Rensselaer's Center for Computational Innovations (CCI) . This new system comprised of 16 extremely large compute nodes, each with 2 POWER9 CPUs, 4 NVIDIA V100 GPUs, 512 GB of DRAM, 1.6 TB of high-speed NVMe non-volatile storage provides over 500 teraflops (TF) of double precision compute power and over 7.6 peta-ops of mixed precision compute power via tensor cores on the GPUs. This represents at least a 3x performance increase over the mixed precision capabilities of our previous IBM Blue Gene/Q supercomputer.

Enabled by the computational capabilities of this cyberinstrument, the CCI is currently supporting $76,793,287 in externally funded research projects for the current 2020--2021 performance period. Of that nearly $77M, $30M was used to purchase in October, 2019 a 14 rack extension to this initial NSF-MRI POWER9/GPU supercomputer as part of an agreement between IBM, RPI and New York State for the AI Testbed, called "AiMOS", which is part of the larger IBM/New York AI Hardware Center.

One of the key outcomes from this NSF activity is a founding membership role in the COVID-19/High-Performance Computing Consortium (see: https://www.xsede.org/covid19-hpc-consortium) which provides an allocation on the AiMOS and NSF-MRI supercomputer systems for COVID-19 computational and data analytic research projects.  In Q2 2021,  the CCI provided 158,993 compute-node hours to COVID-19/HPC Consortium projects. Using our NSF-MRI system as a unit of measure, that collective allocation would consume the whole NSF-MRI system for over 470 days. Because, both IBM and RPI have agreed to be founding members of this consortium, a significant allocation on the AiMOS supercomputer as well as the NSF-MRI 1 rack system have been granted to this international computational research consortium.

For the 2018-2019 performance period, this NSF MRI cyberinfrastructure supported research projects from 34 faculty research groups yielding 94 publications. For the 2019-2020 performance period, projects from 26 faculty were supported yielding an additional 60 publications. Finally, for the 2020-2021 performance period, 34 faculty research groups yielding 99 publications.

Throughout its lifespan, the computational capabilities of this cyberinstrument has supported the educational and research programs across a wide spectrum of scientific and engineering fields of study.  These fields include: Biology; Biomedical Engineering; Chemical and Biological Engineering; Computer Science; Data Science; Electrical, Computers and Systems Engineering; Mathematics; Mechanical, Aerospace and Nuclear Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering and Physics.
